name: Bell & Howell Projector 621: This picture has been edited for content
description: The Bell & Howell-Gaumont Model 621 projector was originally used entertain the shearers on a sheep farm in South Australia with the films screened sometimes edited for distribution.

key_work.title: Model 621 Sound Projector with tripod and stand
key_work.credit_line: ACMI Collection. Tripod donated by Daryl Annett.
key_work.brief_description: In 1951, this projector was brought to the Koomooloo Station in South Australia to entertain workers during the shearing season.

start.title: Aladdin
start.creator_credit: John Musker, Ron Clements, Walt Disney Animation Studios, Walt Disney Pictures, R.S. vander Wende, Ted Elliott, Terry Rossio, Brian Pimental, Burny Mattinson, Chris Sanders, Daan Jippes, Darrell Rooney, David Scott Smith, Francis Glebas, James Fujii, Kevin Harkey, Kevin Lima, Kirk Hanson, Larry Leker, Patrick A. Ventura, Rebecca Reese, Roger Allers and Sue C. Nichols
start.brief_description: Princess Jasmine grows tired of being forced to remain in the palace, so she sneaks out into the marketplace, in disguise, where she meets street-urchin Aladdin. The couple falls in love, although Jasmine may only marry a prince. After being thrown in jail, Aladdin becomes embroiled in a plot to find a mysterious lamp, with which the evil Jafar hopes to rule the land.

constellations_other.name: Cautionary tales and magic lantern projectors
constellations_other.description: Early magic lantern projections depicted cautionary religious scenes and fairytales, just like cinema did in its infancy.

constellations_other.name: Bell & Howell Projector 621: This picture has been edited for content
constellations_other.description: The Bell & Howell-Gaumont Model 621 projector was originally used entertain the shearers on a sheep farm in South Australia with the films screened sometimes edited for distribution.

end.title: Babe: Pig in the City
end.creator_credit: George Miller, Norma Moriceau, Bill Miller, Doug Mitchell, Kennedy Miller Productions, Universal Pictures, Roger Ford, Judy Morris and Mark Lamprell
end.brief_description: Babe, fresh from his victory in the sheepherding contest, returns to Farmer Hoggett’s farm, but after Farmer Hoggett is injured and unable to work, Babe has to go to the big city to save the farm.

constellations_other.name: Bell & Howell Projector 621: This picture has been edited for content
constellations_other.description: The Bell & Howell-Gaumont Model 621 projector was originally used entertain the shearers on a sheep farm in South Australia with the films screened sometimes edited for distribution.

links.description: After test screenings of Babe: Pig in the City, proved too scary for children, director George Miller similarly needed to re-edit. Removing or lessening the intensity of scenes where the animal stars were put in situations dramatically close to death.

start.title: Model 621 Sound Projector with tripod and stand

end.title: The Story of the Kelly Gang
end.credit_line: Courtesy the National Film and Sound Archive of Australia.
end.brief_description: Produced in Melbourne in 1906, The Story of the Kelly Gang is the world’s first feature-length film. While most movies of its era only ran for about 12 minutes, Charles Tait’s bushranger epic went for over an hour.

constellations_primary.name: Outlawed
constellations_primary.description: From The Story of the Kelly Gang to Sweet Country, this Constellation explores bushrangers, samurai and bandits.

constellations_other.name: Crime doesn't pay
constellations_other.description: Ned Kelly's famous armour has appeared in many films, but the criminal myth speaks to how audiences have always been captivated by true-crime stories, from the beginning of cinema to today.

constellations_other.name: Bell & Howell Projector 621: This picture has been edited for content
constellations_other.description: The Bell & Howell-Gaumont Model 621 projector was originally used entertain the shearers on a sheep farm in South Australia with the films screened sometimes edited for distribution.

constellations_other.name: True blue, true crime
constellations_other.description: Robert Connolly's The Dry is a recent Australian crime blockbuster, but the writer, director and producer's first film (and first crime film) connects to a longstanding tradition of true-blue crime stories from some of our greatest filmmakers.

links.description: Popular films such as The Story of the Kelly Gang would regularly tour the country via travelling distributors. At times films would be re-edited to remove scenes that might be bothersome to different audiences, censoring the film’s original narratives.

end.title: Booksmart
end.creator_credit: Olivia Wilde, April Napier, Chelsea Barnard, David Distenfeld, Jessica Elbaum, Katie Silberman, Megan Ellison, Annapurna Pictures, Gloria Sanchez Productions, Katie Byron, Emily Halpern, Sarah Haskins and Susanna Fogel
end.brief_description: Two academic teenage superstars realize, on the eve of their high school graduation, that they should have worked less and played more. Determined to never fall short of their peers, the girls set out on a mission to cram four years of fun into one night.

constellations_other.name: Bell & Howell Projector 621: This picture has been edited for content
constellations_other.description: The Bell & Howell-Gaumont Model 621 projector was originally used entertain the shearers on a sheep farm in South Australia with the films screened sometimes edited for distribution.

links.description: Booksmart was similarly re-edited for content when it was screened on US airline Delta. Controversially same-sex love scenes as well as references to female sexuality were removed or muted for the screenings, angering director Olivia Wilde and many Booksmart fans.

start.title: Booksmart
start.creator_credit: Olivia Wilde, April Napier, Chelsea Barnard, David Distenfeld, Jessica Elbaum, Katie Silberman, Megan Ellison, Annapurna Pictures, Gloria Sanchez Productions, Katie Byron, Emily Halpern, Sarah Haskins and Susanna Fogel
start.brief_description: Two academic teenage superstars realize, on the eve of their high school graduation, that they should have worked less and played more. Determined to never fall short of their peers, the girls set out on a mission to cram four years of fun into one night.

end.title: Titanic
end.creator_credit: James Cameron, Deborah Lynn Scott, Jon Landau, 20th Century Fox, Lightstorm Entertainment, Paramount, Peter Lamont and John Bruno
end.brief_description: 101-year-old Rose DeWitt Bukater tells the story of her life aboard the Titanic, 84 years later. A young Rose boards the ship with her mother and fiancé. Meanwhile, Jack Dawson and Fabrizio De Rossi win third-class tickets aboard the ship. Rose tells the whole story from Titanic’s departure through to its death—on its first and last voyage—on April 15, 1912.

constellations_other.name: Faking history
constellations_other.description: The Great takes a creative approach to its historical characters and settings that is mirrored in its costumes - this war dress might have a classic silhouette, but the grimy pearlescent fabric and striking oxblood detailing is completely modern. Faking history is a time-honoured tradition in film, from historical fiction to propaganda.

constellations_other.name: Bell & Howell Projector 621: This picture has been edited for content
constellations_other.description: The Bell & Howell-Gaumont Model 621 projector was originally used entertain the shearers on a sheep farm in South Australia with the films screened sometimes edited for distribution.

constellations_other.name: Quiet luxury, loud transformations
constellations_other.description: In The Dressmaker, Gertrude (Sarah Snook) transforms from 'dowdy' to elegant when she attends a dance in this dress. It's a popular cinema trope that shows how characters develop, but the 'makeover' trope isn't always a positive.

constellations_other.name: From queer period romances to surrealistic worlds
constellations_other.description: Explore the interconnections between queer period dramas, through to sci-fi and surrealistic worlds.

links.description: James Cameron’s Titanic also faced cuts when a scene featuring Kate Winslet’s exposed breasts was deemed culturally insensitive to China’s ban on pornographic content. Cameron felt it was better to extend the cultural impact of the film and so cut the scene for the Chinese release.

links.description: Arab American Anti-Discrimination groups demanded that lyrics to ‘Arabian Nights’ be changed because of its portrayal of Arabic people as violent barbarians. “Where they cut off your ear/If they don’t like your face” became “Where it’s flat and immense/and the heat is intense”.

end.title: South Park: The Stick of Truth
end.brief_description: From the perilous battlefields of the fourth-grade playground, a young hero will rise, destined to be South Park’s savior.

constellations_other.name: Bell & Howell Projector 621: This picture has been edited for content
constellations_other.description: The Bell & Howell-Gaumont Model 621 projector was originally used entertain the shearers on a sheep farm in South Australia with the films screened sometimes edited for distribution.

links.description: South Park: The Stick of Truth videogame was also edited for its Australian release. Objectionable scenes which included alien probing were replaced with an image of a crying Koala bear and written text explaining what was removed from the original scene.
